newsitem.title: USA: American Exploration battles US Gulf blowout.
newsitem.headline: American Exploration battles US Gulf blowout.

text.p: Crews on a pair of supply boats equipped with water cannons on Tuesday were battling to contain flames from a blowout in the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana, a federal official said.

A drilling rig and production platform over natural gas and oil wells operated by American Exploration Co caught fire and a derrick collapsed in the blowout shortly after 0100 CST Tuesday, a company spokeswoman said.
The blowout occured over wells in East Cameron 328, a shallow-water block located in federal waters about 115 miles off the coast of Louisiana, the spokesman said
Fifty one workers were evacuated safely and crews from the company, along with federal regulators and firefighters from International Well Control were at the scene, he said.
"I guess right now pople are assesing how to put the fire out and how to go from here," company spokesman Frank Murphy said of flames shooting 30 feet into the sky.
Oil from the well formed a mile-long sheen that was dissipating, and little environmental damage was expected from the clean-burning, largely natural gas-fed fire, he said.
"My understanding is there is considerable damage to the drilling rig and probably going to be significant damage to the production platform," Murphy said.

American Exploration acquired the field last year and had completed three in a series of production wells. The platform was producing 7 million cubic feet per day of natural gas and recently began production of 350 barrels of oil per day (bpd), which was expected to rise to 1,000 bpd, he said.

"The impact on us will be in delaying what we expected to be good oil production," Murphy said. "What this event will do is delay what we had hoped will be a fairly substantial increase in oil and gas production in the second quarter."
